New Hampshire's Mount Washington, the highest mountain in the Northeast, is attracting more visitors every year.
But it's also home to delicate ecosystems that some fear could suffer from overuse.
New Hampshire Public Radio's Annie Ropeik has this story from the summit on how to keep that peak welcoming but wild.
As you near the top of Mount Washington, the trees get shorter and shorter and finally disappear.
This is the alpine zone - a bare, windswept slope of yellow-green grass, endangered flowers and fragile lichens.
I can see some deer's hair sedge, Bigelow's sedge.
And there's some Lapland rosebay.
Naturalist David Govatski first climbed the mountain when he was 14.
Since then, he's climbed every foot of the region's 1,400 miles of trails.
He leads me down one of them - an ankle-bending, rocky path that's part of the Appalachian Trail.
And he points down the mountainside.
That's actually the area where the hotel would be.
You can see how close it would be.
Hi, there.
Can you hear me all right?
The hotel is a plan from the Mount Washington Cog Railway, which runs tourist trains up the mountain and owns a narrow strip of land for its tracks.
The potential hotel would straddle those tracks in the alpine zone.
But not everyone's on board.
Molly Carmody from Massachusetts is hiking by on her way to the summit.
She thinks this place should remain an escape from society.
To get to someplace where you can only get by the power of your body is pretty cool.
But right above us, there are hundreds of people at the summit visitors center who did not use their bodies to get here.
Hiking is not the only way to scale Mount Washington.
You can pay to take the train or drive the hairpin turns of a private toll road.
Both have been here since the 1800s.
And they're getting more popular every year.
In the gift shop, with windows looking out on panoramic views and high blue sky, Jodie Heal and her 5-year-old son Austin are buying postcards to send home to family in Maine.
They drove the mountain last time they visited and took the train this year.
Heal says she's not sure they'd have come if the summit had no facilities.
Especially traveling will children, they don't always hike very well, so it's nice when we get up here that if they're hungry, we can get food.
And if they want to get a souvenir, they can.
So...
Outside, dozens of people wait in line for a photo with a pile of rocks marking the summit.
And Cog Railway trains chug out of their station, heading down the mountain.
I meet Cog owner Wayne Presby at their base station.
He says his hotel could boost this rural economy and ease the strain on other overcrowded mountain facilities.
I think we're one of the key pieces of the economy for Mount Washington and for tourism in general in the state of New Hampshire.
Presby would need a special county permit to build his hotel in the alpine zone.
But he thinks it'd be worth it.
He says people who don't hike up the mountain want to enjoy that environment just as much as hikers do.
And he thinks they'll respect it.
People like to visit mountain tops, and not all of them are capable of hiking.
People need refuge when the weather gets bad, so I think there's any number of reasons why there's a need for additional facilities up there.
This year, New Hampshire plans to find out exactly how much need there is with a study of Mount Washington's carrying capacity.
It could help settle some debate over if and how this iconic summit can be accessible to everyone and still remain wild.
For NPR News, I'm Annie Ropeik.
When old TVs and computers end up in landfills or incinerators, the heavy metals and flame retardants they contain can cause pollution.
States have been looking for solutions to this e-waste problem, and Washington State has come up with one.
It now requires manufacturers to pay the entire cost of recycling computers and TVs.
From member station KUOW in Seattle, Ann Dornfeld reports.
Remember that laptop you took such good care of for years?
Well, today a guy in a warehouse is bashing it apart with a hammer.
(Soundbite of hammering)
If the first step in the computer-recycling process was hard to listen to, you might want to cover your ears for a few seconds as the guts of your computer are pulled out piece by piece.
Each goes into a separate chute.
(Soundbite of metal clanging)
Then into a gigantic Cuisinart.
And your computer has been turned into confetti.
As confetti goes, it's pretty valuable.
There are precious metals in the circuit boards.
The steel and aluminum will be sold to refineries and smelters, too.
Still, the Environmental Protection Agency says in 2007, more than 80 percent of all old computers, monitors and TVs ended up in the trash.
These kinds of materials all need to be safely managed.
Miles Kuntz manages the electronics-recycling program for the Washington State Department of Ecology.
Well, the cathode ray tubes contain four to eight pounds of lead, depending on the size of the tube.
There's also mercury.
There's cadmium and PBEs, which are flame retardants.
Some states have made it illegal to throw e-waste in the trash.
Others sponsor e-waste recycling programs, but these programs are expensive, and the cost is expected to spike this year as people get rid of their old analog TVs for the digital conversion.
Now, Washington State thinks it has the solution.
Starting this year, every manufacturer that sells TVs, computers or monitors there must pay for all residential recycling of those products.
The state's working with the manufacturers to create a network of drop-off centers, from recycling facilities to thrift stores.
Miles Kuntz says at first, a lot of manufacturers weren't too happy.

So the idea that Sony, Apple, and all the other smaller manufacturers as well, had to register with Washington, pay an administrative fee to the state of Washington, and then get ready to pay for recycling, that was a real hard pill for them to swallow.
But they've come around to the fact that that is a new business cost.
That new business cost is known as producer responsibility: holding manufacturers accountable for the full life cycle of their products.
Sarah Westervelt heralds the new law.
She's the coordinator with the non-profit Basel Action Network, which works to keep toxic waste out of the environment.

The notion is that if a manufacturer has to pay for the end-of-life costs, the recycling costs for their products, that they will have an economic incentive to redesign them so there are no toxins in them, or fewer toxins in them, and so they are more easily broken down and recycled - and maybe so that they even last longer.
Douglas Smith directs corporate environmental affairs for Sony Electronics.
He says it doesn't work that way.
We redesign products because of what - it's what our customers want, and we see this as a global requirement.
But the state regulation itself doesn't have that result.
Still, Smith says Sony will comply with Washington's new law, as well as other, smaller-scale recycling laws that have popped up in other states.
He says what Sony would like to see, though, is one, federal-produced responsibility law for electronics recycling so manufacturers don't have to juggle different state requirements.

Where do things stand right now in the effort to find a compromise?
Well, we continue to work with one another.
There's a lot of discussions going back and forth, telephone calls, talking about language in a proposed agreement.
As time comes to the end here, obviously, we're all looking for a solution and an agreement, and I think if we're able to achieve it, we'll be able to achieve it tonight.
And how would a proposed compromise work?
Well, a compromise would do at least two things.
One is it would assure, in most cases of judicial nominees, an up or down vote.

It would not bind my colleagues on the Democratic side or Republican side to vote for cloture against certain nominees, but it would--for the most part, it would stop the filibustering of most judicial nominations.
On the second side, it would also suspend any effort by the Republicans to move toward the nuclear option.

In other words, it would resolve the impasse and let us move forward on judicial nominees, but at the same time, begin the important work that we must pick up on, and that's the energy bill and a whole host of other similar items.

So as I understand it, the descriptions in the papers this morning, at least five of the seven most controversial nominees would be guaranteed a vote on the floor; at the same time, Democrats would preserve the option, in some cases, of filibuster.
That's correct.

It would reserve the right and the option of filibustering, but wouldn't guarantee that the filibuster would be used even in those cases, but it would make it clear that if each senator felt, in his or her opinion, that a particular nominee involved exceptional circumstances--extraordinary is the word that's used--then they could vote against that--they could vote for the filibuster or, in effect, against cloture.
